```{r}
library(tidyverse)
```

```{r}
nbalogs_2024 <- read_csv("~/GitHub/jour479x_fall_2025/presentations/2025nbadata.csv")
```

```{r}
centerlogs_2024 <- nbalogs_2024 |> filter(Pos =="C")
```

This dataset only contains statistics from the 2024-25 NBA season, though it contains entries from 103 centers. For the purpose of my project (analyzing how the playstyle of NBA centers has changed since 2000), I'll take the average number of assists per game, three point attempts, three point percentage, and rebounds per game.

```{r}
centeraverages_2024 <- centerlogs_2024 |> rename("ThreePointAtt" = `3PA`) |> rename("ThreePointPct" = `3P%`) |> na.omit(centerlogs_2024) |>  summarise(
  AverageAssists = mean(AST),
  AverageRebounds = mean(TRB),
  Average3PTATT = mean(ThreePointAtt),
  Average3PTPCT = mean(ThreePointPct * 100),
)

centeraverages_2024 <- centeraverages_2024 |> mutate(Year = "2024")
```

My next step would be to load every dataset since 2000, which would be tedious but doable. Then, I could create a line chart showing the change in the four metrics that I measured. The method of calculating the average of all four statistics is fairly simple, which makes my question easier to answer.

The average height of centers - and the analysis of the "small ball" lineups that were prevalent throughout the NBA in the 2010s - would be a bit more difficult though. I would have to link that data to my data imported from Basketball Reference.

```{r}
center_averages <- rbind(centeraverages_2000, centeraverages_2001, centeraverages_2002, centeraverages_2003, centeraverages_2004, centeraverages_2005, centeraverages_2006, centeraverages_2007, centeraverages_2008, centeraverages_2009, centeraverages_2010, centeraverages_2011, centeraverages_2012, centeraverages_2013, centeraverages_2014, centeraverages_2015, centeraverages_2016, centeraverages_2017, centeraverages_2018, centeraverages_2019, centeraverages_2020, centeraverages_2021, centeraverages_2022, centeraverages_2023, centeraverages_2024)
```

```{r}
center_averages_assists <- center_averages |> select(AverageAssists, Year)
```

```{r}
ggplot() + geom_line(data = center_averages_assists, aes(x = Year, y = AverageAssists, group = 1)) + scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 4.5))
```


```{r}
ggplot() + geom_point(data = centerlogs_2023, aes(x = AST, y = PTS))
```


```{r}
jokic <- centerlogs_2023 |> filter(Player == "Nikola JokiÄ‡")
sabonis <- centerlogs_2023 |> filter(Player == "Domantas Sabonis")

ggplot() +
  geom_point(data = centerlogs_2023, aes(x = AST, y = PTS)) +
  geom_point(data = jokic, aes(x = AST, y = PTS), color = "gold") +
  geom_point(data = sabonis, aes(x = AST, y = PTS), color = "purple")
```

Before my presentation, I will update this with chatter explaining my findings and couple of other data visualizations, such as a stacked bar chart displaying the league's total three point attempts over time with the percentage of three-pointers taken by center. I'll also create line charts for rebounds per game, three-point attempts per game, and three-point percentage by year.

All my graphs will be finalized with titles, subtitles, and labels. I also plan on importing height data from NBA.com and appending that to the center_averages data frame.
